185425494.review:
Hello and welcome to my review of Source Filmmaker. After spending 2–3 years working in this program, I can confidently recommend it to beginner animators who want to start their journey into the world of animation. However, like any software, it has its pros and cons, and unfortunately, there are more cons than pros here—but we’ll get to that shortly.  

What is Source Filmmaker? Source Filmmaker is a program designed for creating animations using characters from Valve games like Half-Life, Half-Life 2, Left 4 Dead 2, and Team Fortress 2 (at least those are the games I remember). SFM also offers a Workshop where users can publish their own models, maps imported from different games, or other custom assets. At first, the program may seem difficult to use because of all the buttons and options available, but once you get the hang of it, it’s as easy as anything.  

I’ve spent the hours you can see on my account in this program, and as I said, I can confidently recommend it. However, Source Filmmaker is so poorly optimized for importing assets, etc., that the program often crashes or throws errors when importing maps into SFM (like "CUUBBTree overflow!"). This is one of the cons, namely the "frequent crashes."  

I eventually ended my journey with this program and gave up because it crashed on me so many times over the last two years. I finally couldn’t take it anymore, and at 10:01 AM (GMT+1) on January 12, 2025, I uninstalled the program after importing a model that caused it to crash.  

Pros:  
- Easy to use for beginners, great entry point for animators and those new to animation.  
- Easily accessible models and particles via the Source Filmmaker Steam Workshop.  
- The SFM community is fantastic, and I love it.  
- Source Engine compatibility allows you to work on maps built for this engine, offering realistic lighting and shadows based on older software.  
- You can import assets from other programs, such as Blender.  
- Free to use, no cost to get started.  

Cons:  
- Extremely outdated; the program hasn’t been updated in 8 years.  
- Creating highly realistic movements requires a lot of work and patience.  
- Rendering animations can take forever. (you need more Ram)
- No support for modern technologies like ray tracing or idk.  
- Valve has completely abandoned Source Filmmaker. Instead of continuing to update this program, which still has potential, they focus on Counter-Strike 2, which itself is only occasionally updated (and even then, they sometimes ignore bugs).  
- Importing models and other assets, like those from Blender, is hard.  

Thank you for allowing me to be part of the Source Filmmaker community for 2–3 years. I’ve been interested in animation for 5 years, and I wish you all success in creating animations and achieving your career goals with this program.  

What’s next for me? I’m moving on to Blender to explore its potential. After spending 500 hours in it, I plan to write a review for that program too.  

Special Thanks:  
I want to thank everyone who supported me during my Source Filmmaker career. Here’s the list:  
- Hoovytube  
- Halal07  
- Strider  
- Rymen  
- SkE!?mie!  
- Farradasthel  
- Santosλrr's  
- Fran  
- MeleeLuigi  
- Matt  
- Dydder Floutin  
- JamesSFM  
- Gorchyflix  
- DeerFromOhio  
- OneMoreAnimator  
- BourBow  
- Gabriel  
- Leaks' Buddy  
- Savitar Person
